reviewText:
After being gifted this game, I really really want to recommend it, but I just can't. Here's why:

Pros (+) :

1. Pleasant and fitting music though it feels... Not so original.
2. Strong monsters (for those of you who like strong enemies in games) that scale with your level, including their loot.
3. Six different classes to choose from.
4. The character art is pretty, but everything else is what you would expect of a game of that genre, nothing special or unique here.
5. It's possible to upgrade your weapon as well as craft your own potions.
6. It's a fairly cheap game.


Cons (-) :

1. Classes are way too similar to each other. In fact, it doesn't matter which one you pick as they hardly differ from each other at all as there are no special abilities or talents. All of the classes can use the two OP weapons I will mention further down in this review.

2. Unfixed bugs are present in the game. Several of them. You can literally walk on the walls inside the church, an innkeeper won't allow you to enter the room you paid for and you can't walk behind a really tall building.

3. Hardly any balancing in melee fights: Enemies have more hp and hit harder as you level, while you hardly become any stronger. In fact, it wasn't unusual for enemies to be able to kill me with 2-3 hits once I leveled up just a few times. And that was indeed as a melee class with a higher defense stat than mages and archers. Also, there are two swords that can be used by ALL classes, and those swords can kill just about every monster without them ever being able to hit you as you hit them diagonally, while they can only harm you when you are in their path.

4. Spells are useless: only 2 spells and they don't really do any major damage. Also, enemies apparently have a 2 second or so invulnerability after being hit, which isn't much of an issue when using melee weapons (as a melee weapon takes about equally long to charge the attack), but it's a major issue when using spells as you have to time the spell right so you don't waste mana nor get hit while waiting for their invulnerability to wear off. Unnecesarily hard and really bothersome.

5. Very few quests for a game of that genre: I could only find 4 in the game and I literally looked everywhere and talked to every single npc in the game. Oh and they don't really give any directions so you more or less have to guess where to go for x quest.

6. Lacks content: Like I wrote above, enemies become stronger the higher level you are, and so it would be nice if you could buy or acquire better armor, but there isn't anything meant for mid-game fights and above. Also, why is there a random guy living in the middle of nowhere when he does nothing important? Why does everyone talk about the king and all when he actually proves to be completely irrelevant to the story and is, in fact, impossible to interact with?

7. Incomplete (or feels so) things: why are there guard towers with instructions on how to use smoke signals if you don't ever get to use it yourself or see it happen? Why are there so many locked doors?

8. Doesn't really have a lot of different weapons to offer: Again, no need to acquire any other weapon than one of the two swords mentioned above.

9. The crafting / upgrading system is more or less useless. Once you acquire either one of the swords (again with the swords…), you can literally just kill monsters without them ever being able to hit you, and only standard weapons sold by npcs can be upgraded, and the upgraded weapons are FAR inferior to those two swords. As for making your own potions, well, using OP swords will give you so much money that you will easily be able to buy more potions than you could ever need. Oh and if you really want to make your own potions, farming the ressources is a major pain and nearly impossible to do, as nothing says where to acquire them (apart from those blue butterflies). Just farm gold kay?.

10. No fast travel" or "teleport to x city/town": It's really annoying to travel through several zones 10 times while trying to avoid monsters (in EVERY zone) that can almost kill you with one hit.

11. It's a fairly short game (fortunately?). I beat it first time as a ninja (the slow and long play-through to explore everything the game has to offer

reviewText:
Secret of Magia is an Action RPG developed with RPG Maker.
I was given a key by the developer and I am sorry to say I do not recommend this game and here is why.

Let's start with the good things first :
The game offers not only between the choice of a female or male character, but features a class system that determines what can you equip. The HUD is nicely done and the quest system is rather original for a game like this.
The combat system is pretty good and the enemies are implemented in a smart way, the skeletons in the mines were one of them, as they genuinely surprised me and made me paranoid.
Another nice thing is that you can gather flowers and butterflies for the crafting system, sadly after an hour and a half I have not tried this system yet, but I gathered quite a lot of stuff.

Now for the bad parts :
I'm not sure if the developer has tested this game, but it's full of bugs, you can go inside walls, letters become plants when you read them, some blocks that should be solid are not, some that shouldn't be are, glitches here and there, couches have teleport blocks inside them, I was joking with a friend that in the first chuch you come across you can ascend to godhood by straight walking on the wall, most of the walls there are passable, even npcs climb them.
The combat while original for the first half hour, is kind of unbalanced, at least as a melee class, I was getting oneshotted the first levels which was pretty frustrating (slimes), I had to align myself diagonally so the monsters wouldn't have a chance to attack me but I could. I farmed a little, when I leveled up though, the monsters leveled with me and became a lot more tanky, giving more gold too. Now, the first real boss was not a big problem because by the time I had so many money I invested in health potions, he could never kill me, doesn't matter how much damage he did to me. After that you drop a legendary weapon which is a bow, a weapon my assassin shouldn't be using but he was using anyway (not sure if legendary weapons do not have class requirements). Some of the resources are inherent to RPG Maker and not original by the developer, you can judge if that affects quality or not.
I do not feel compelled to complete or continue the game as I did not have much fun with it, but thank you anyway for this chance (since I received the key by a developer or someone in contact with him).
All in all it's a low quality rpg maker title with some smart ideas here and there, but with a weak story, characters and quite full of bugs at the moment of writing, so personally I would not recommend you this game.

reviewText:
Secret Of Magia is an action RPG that was made using RPG Maker.
It is inspired by games like The Legend of Zelda: A Link To The Past, Arc The Lad and Secret of Mana and takes you back to the NES/SNES days.

The game starts by selecting between a male/female character that you can later specialize in one out of 6 classes.
There is no tutorial in the game that shows you how to do certain things.
There is also no main quest or other information regarding the storyline, you have to find that out by yourself which is a good thing in my opinion.

While I really like the combat system and the sounds/music this game has a few main issues that need to be addressed like:

- Low texture quality
Because of low quality assets things get pixelated quickly and sometimes it is really hard to read certain things (in the UI for example).

- Missing widescreen support
Widescreen resolution should be supported in every modern game.
It would be great to have an options menu to select the desired screen resolution / aspect ratio.

- Missing key binding customization
Want to move your character by using WASD instead of the arrow keys? Not possible to change this anywhere unfortunately.

Other than these issues the game has a couple of minor bugs and design flaws, but nothing really game breaking.

All in all I can say that this is a solid game for a cheap price.
If you are into these type of retro action/adventure RPG's you should definitely consider buying this game.

Disclaimer: I was generously given a free copy of Secret of Magia with the understanding that I was expected to review the title after spending some time with it.

I had braced myself for yet another piece of RPG Maker garbage when I first loaded this game up. It took me joyfully by surprise when it turned out to actually be a real time adventure game similar to that of the old top-down Zelda titles. Hookshot included!

Sadly, the magic didn’t last as I quickly found that nothing felt quite responsive or snappy enough. The sword swung in a pitifully small arc, the character feels very locked down to a square grid of movement, and actually trying to naturally navigate with a controller or D-pad is very uncomfortable. Even the hookshot moseys across the screen like a tranquilized snail. The story wasn’t dreadful from the little bit I saw of it. The creatures, while rather disjointed and inconsistent in theme, were decently drawn and animated. However, when it comes down to it, playing Secret of Magia makes you reminisce of Zelda and sulk over how inferior this game feels in comparison.

reviewText:
A technically flawed but mostly charming and low priced action adventure/RPG title, Secret Of Magia harkens back to older action adventure RPG titles and the inspirations and love for the Zelda titles is clear, and things like the friendly dialogue, brief random encounters, art style and music all fit nicely. There's also a fair amount of content, areas and enemies for the cost, and overall, while it has problems and does nothing special, it's good value for money and a competent aaRPG.

Full disclosure: I recieved a Steam key prior to this review.

Highlights
The variety of environments and pretty good intro level were enough to get me engaged, and the casual and unlimited nature of exploration from an early stage are worth mentioning. It's easy to skip ahead if you're impatient, but equally easy to spend an extra hour or two just exploring and grinding. There's also a variety of competent and occasionally funny dialogue from many different denizens in many different towns.
The music is also very pleasant to listen to, and sets the tone really well without getting annoying at all.

Overall, if the developer releases a patch or two and clears up some issues, this title will be worth picking up for what is essentially the price of a coffee.

Mistakes and Annoyances
I feel like a patch or two would fix up most of my complaints, but for the sake of completion and honesty here they are.

There are tons of small technical bugs. I routinely found myself clipping through walls and into inaccessible areas, I was unable to equip or de-equip items after certain encounters, and had no way to continue but to slowly suicide, menu systems sometimes became disabled for unidentifiable reasons and plenty more small annoying technical mistakes that should've been play-tested and fixed.
The support for using a mouse is great, and makes playing a lot faster and smoother, but the out of the box key bindings are frankly awful, and the in-game configuration panel isn't listed in the controls, nor accessible by anything other than messing around (it's F1 in all RPG Maker titles), and even that isn't properly labelled or actionable, and F12 causes crashes due to a bugged RPG Maker script. Again, these are little things that can be fixed fairly simply, but that's all the more reason to highlight them.

There are design mistakes too, namely the save system relying on positional altar markers. This means that, like some of the older Zelda systems, you can only save before entering an area or after travelling to a specific place. For a game that encourages player grinding and a slow death screen, this makes little sense. An auto-save or simply just a save button would've been a far better choice.
The main issue for me, however, was the combat. There is arguably a small level of skill required in coordinating where to position the player in regards to each enemy and the environment but, at least as the soldier class, it's mostly just about finding the next diagonal tile and slashing ad infinitum and became repetitive and bland after a short time and even boss fights are mostly about predicting the next move and getting in position.

Recommendations
Priced at just £1.99/2.99€/$2.99 at the time of review, this is actually priced fairly, and will probably be worth picking up on sale for someone looking for a casual aaRPG with a nod towards older Nintendo titles, just not until some of the technical problems are corrected.

reviewText:
It's rare that I will post a review for a game that I haven't completed in full, but I just can't bring myself to do much more than finish out the achievements and then give up Secret of Magia.

From the store page, the game looks like it will be a fun and fast paced RPG with dark, gothic graphics. However, when you play the game, you realize that it's the opposite of all those things. The color scheme and tones of the graphics are nothing as they are presented on the store page, which is very misleading. You can easily go around and avoid all of the monster fights; the monsters will not follow you or go out of their way to hit you. The only real fast-paced action here is how fast the main character moves.

The BIGGEST downfall of this game are the controls, whether you're playing with KB or a controller. It's just horrendous either way. I'm not sure how the developer even thought that the control scheme was a good idea in the first place. It's barely feasible on a controller, but downright hand breaking on a KB.

I should also mention here that any time you quit the game, the game crashes instead of closing properly. There is also no way to adjust your resolution or if you'd rather have full screen or windowed mode. Steam overlay also does not work in the game, but toast windows pop up and leave an annoying white rectangle on the corner of the screen.

At the paid price of a whopping $0.32 CAD, I can't say I'm upset. I got it at this price for the achievements, honestly. But anyone who is seriously considering this title for pleasure play should think twice. Don't support misleading store pages and broken games.

The start of the game is fuzzy - Firstly player picks a character between male and female and then a short cutscene is shown where some gigantic bird looking creature tells protogonist to find and bring 4 elements or else to be eliminated. The fighting system works decently though. Battles are fought in real time and assaulting at enemy head over heels is not an option. I could complain forever, but still - with all its weaknesses The Secret of Magia is not a total bummer. It has priced itself modestly and some features work but it is the competition which makes it look bad. There is numerous respected JRPGs developed with RPG maker in steam. They might be more expensive but do have much much more content and quality than this game.

reviewText:
Secret of Magia is an ARPG made in RPGmaker. It is not like other RPGmaker game, as it is not turn-based... It's more of an action game.

The pathing of monsters and their attacks are quite frustating to play against, some just dash to you in zigzag kinda patterns and are almost impossible to dodge. On the other hand, with anything but a dagger or a bow, you can sit next to monsters and kill them to your side. With a bow, you can just kill them from afar without them trying to kill you.

It could have been a great game, but there are too many flaws. Mana regen is slow, leveling-up actually makes the monsters harder to kill overall. Classes are a little meaningless and have no really specific skills. There's also no abilities to unlock as you gain levels.

There's no maps, so you have to keep the layout of the map in your head and the game is just pretty, bland... In the first 2 dungeons anyways, all you have to do is kill the unique monster inside the zone, get his key and then unlock the door that leads to the boss room, that's not very original!

The music is not too bad, but I heard it wasn't composed for this game, so I won't praise it too much. The graphics are fair enough for RPGmaker, but they could be way better. There are some game breaking bugs (just pressing f12 for example, it crashes your game). The game is also very short.

The game is really cheap, about $1, but even there, it's not a game I would really recommend playing. If you are a fan of RPGmaker games, then maybe this is for you, otherwise, I did not enjoy it very much, it is a bit too clunky and unfun to play.

reviewText:
It's a quickly-played, quickly-made RPG Maker action RPG game.  RPG Maker notoriously handles anything but the turn-based actions it was made to handle quite poorly, so the game can be clunky at times, but it's not QUITE as bad as most action RPGs on RPG maker is.  Still, I would suggest looking to something made in another engine for any substansive action RPG fix, because this game is anemic in content, and has no interesting gimmicks to make it stand out compared to the hundred other Zelda-wannabes on Steam.

Pros:
* Dirt cheap, so you won't regret it long even if you don't like it.
* It's fairly fast-paced, and you level up quickly with relatively little grinding.
* It's possible to just run past most of the enemies.
* Six possible classes.
* If you aren't going for cards, you can beat the game fast enough to return it for a refund!

Cons:
* The enemies are rubber-banded to your level, while your stat-boosting equipment is based upon how far in the plot you have progressed, meaning you lose power relative to your enemies as you gain levels.
* The enemies meander around until it's time for their attack, at which point they fly at you at mach 12, clip through your own attacks, and keep chasing you even if you do hit them in the middle of their attack.
* You have a shield button, but except for the archer, you have to be a melee class to get it, and there's no wind-up animation to warn you to raise your shield before they start running at you, so you need to use psychic precognition to tell when to use your shield when you're standing only 1-2 tiles away.
* The enemies deal about 1/5 your total health per hit.
* The enemies have about second-long invulnerability after being hit, and can attack immediately after that.
* The enemies can stun-lock you in place with spammed ranged attacks
* The classes are not described in-game at all, and have unintuitive effects.
* The classes are not balanced at all.
* The archer class relies upon arrows, can only carry 99 at a time, I shot 50 getting from the first town to the second, and the second town doesn't have arrow vendors.
* The spells deal 1/6th the damage a physical attack does no matter what your magic stat is, so mages are useless.
* All other classes are melee classes, and any melee class besides Paladin is just plain weaker than the Paladin.
* Bugs galore! Walk through walls! Don't walk through objects that look the same as ones you can walk through! Enter one house, leave out a different one!
* The writing is as utterly barebones as possible.  Go kill this thing for me." "Thank you for killing it.  Here's the ___ I promised."
* The plot consists of your character having a dream where a bird tells you to go kill four bosses and bring it their souls or it'll eat your soul.  You find these bosses literally just sitting out in a field

reviewText:
This is probably the first time i'm not recommending a game, so it pains me to do this :(

I can see some potential but this is nowhere near production ready; do not put money towards it. I got a copy in a pack of 4 RPGs i wanted to try for ~60p, thankfully.

Obvious problems:
You get direction for what to do for the first 5 minutes ('Go to the well'), after that, you're free to wander the entire map (and good luck finding a map so you can squint and get an idea of where the hell you are or what you're supposed to be doing.) Quests have no markers - if it says 'go and kill blah', and you don't know where blah is, then so begins a wild goose chase.
After you save the miner...you can go back to the mine with the dungeon key and have a go at the fire boss...but not if you can't equip a shield.

It might just be because i picked the mage class, but i couldn't equip a shield despite buying everything possible (currency is nowhere near balanced, items cost ~30 gold and you can earn 1000s in minutes). No shield? No hope in hell of beating the elemental bosses. Was i supposed to buy 99 health potions and spam those instead??? (for shame)

While normal attack damage is ok and different weapons do different AoE areas (the combat system is quite interesting actually), magic is realllllly weak :/ like not even worth having. It's good for long distance but not when it does 10 damage against an enemy with 1000s of HP - who doesn't always stay STILL - who has time for that?

Enemies are all overpowered - i got to ~lvl 16 and even the wasps were taking off ~1/5 of my health per attack. Only the rats in the well at the very start of the game seem like they're at the right level for your character, and if you go back down there, they can divebomb you to hell and back in seconds.
The screen is littered with annoyance after annoyance and they don't scale with you nor drop anything significant. You're thrown in at the deep-end and get nothing for not drowning.

You can only save at the green flames and not the barely-existent menu, which i thought was a bit annoying because you have to backtrack to the last village and hope you can remember where it is in that village/town - some sign posts really wouldn't go amiss.

NPCs are pretty lifeless - if you ever even find one, chances are they'll just talk about their house (i found books in ONE house, all the other houses are window dressing :/) Ok, Sir/Madam, your house is nice and all....(not if there's nothing to loot lol) but how about some lore or something? Why go on???

I don't hate the game, but it really needs a lot of work. Tone down the difficulty (there doesn't have to be an enemy everywhere), scale enemies to class and level - battles are supposed to be FUN. Put in more 'where to go if you're stuck' (signposts!) . Know your characters - do we get a party at some point?? Why are we being forced by some flying bird to collect all the elements? Because it will 'reap our soul' otherwise? Well that's very nice of it???? haha

Initial Review (bear in mind I only played for an hour before deciding I wouldn't like it):

1. Introduction was quick enough.  However, my interest wasn't piqued much.  A strange bird tells you to get all four elements or he'd reap your soul.  You get to choose your gender and class (assassin, archer or mage).  That's it.

2. You wake up in a city and you're being told what to do next exactly.  The game pushes you in the direction you have to go.  Not much thought process involved at all.

3. The combat system is Zelda-like; Secret of Magia is an action RPG where you press Z to swing your weapon, S to block with a shield, A to cast a spell.  Easy enough at first, but you can be one-shot by some enemies as melee rather easily if you don't act quickly enough.  The shield that I bought from the weaponmaker after receiving the license in town didn't seem to be working either (and I made sure to equip it, too).  And the monsters really do move too fast for you to avoid them sometimes.

4. There are background bugs everywhere.  Cliffs and walls are passable when they shouldn't be, etc.

5. No proofreading has been done for this game, apparently.  Dialogue is full of typos and misspellings - you'll be talking to plenty of 'Gaurds,' for example - and even with that fixed, it's not particularly memorable.  Many of the NPC's lines are nothing special.  I love my nice house!"  One guard said that they couldn't drink in the watchtower and giggled as he said it - which seemed weirdly out of place.

reviewText:
My full review can be found here.[www.the-backlog.net]

Secret of Magia is a game that takes hints from several 2D adventure titles such as Ys, the Mana series, and Zelda. What it fails to do is execute these well and the game just turns into a giant mess. In Secret of Magia, you'll experience game breaking glitches, awful hitboxes, poor English, and a game that just isn't very long at all. The game has a grand total of five dungeons available, though only four of them are actually required to beat the game.

One of the things in Secret of Magia that made absolutely no sense to me was why the enemies scaled with your level. I very quickly decided to not even bother with killing anything but what was required to even proceed. When it comes to the bosses, it doesn't even really matter if you're underleveled. All you have to do is stand to the side of where they can hit, and so long as they don't have some sort of area of effect skill they just can't hit you. One NPC remarked that you needed a shield to beat a particular boss. This boss was actually one of the only ones I couldn't abuse this hitbox effect on and I still never even used the shield (playing as a Paladin).

Secret of Magia holds some good promises but completely fails to deliver on them. Many glitches are being left unchecked, such as being locked out of dungeons forcing you to restart the entire game and the Scythe just not being upgradeable. There are much better games in this style out there, so my suggested is to just play those instead and pass on Secret of Magia. Unless, of course, you don't mind smashing your head into awful English and poor hitboxes.

reviewText:
Full Disclosure
I was given this a copy game by the developer(s) (or someone in contact with them) to review.

Review
Secret of Magia is a bit of an interesting title for me, at first I was rather enjoying it. It had an OK story, some character progression and even some nice things like a HookShot! Unfortunately it went downhill from there (and before that even).

I personally played this game with an Xbox 360 controller, as that's what I generally enjoy playing this style of game with. Sadly there appears to be no documentation of the controls for it.
So here's roughly what they seem to be for me:
A - Run/Walk + Hookshot
B - Menu (Really odd binding IMO)
X - Attack/Interact
Y - Magic
LB - Shield
Select - Quick Menu (also used for cycling between quick menus)
Start - Also used for cycling quick menus, but cannot be used to access it in the first place)
RB/LT/RT - Appear to be unused.

Now while the game was fun for the first hour or so, unforunately it simply became a grindfest of bugs and dull combat. It is worth noting that I played as a Paladin class, so other classes *may* be more interesting, but for me it simply consisted of standing diagonally from an enemy and spamming the attack button (the cooldown on combos seems very short IMO).

This tactic ends up changing slightly for enemies that have a ranged attack as I will simply attack them head on because they have no melee secondary attack, leaving them essentially paralyzed while I attack them. Magic attacks are OK, but they have no cooldown meaning they can easily be spammed. (I only seemed to have access to a fire spell and ice spell as a Paladin, with the ice being a sort of ball shot straight ahead, and the fire being multiple revolving fireballs).

Now you might seem to think that combat isn't so bad from this, but enemies get tougher the higher level you are, the problem is that while their health gets ever higher my attack doesn't seem to level at the same rate (or at all), with most monsters now taking up to 70 (yes seventy) hits to defeat at level 16 with the best weapons I currently have.

I also have ended up with virtually endless money as well from every monster I come across up to the first boss, meaning I can basically never die by drinking as many life potions as needed due to them having no cooldown.

It is also worth noting that the game has no hint system or in-game map (short of the maps you can find on tables in some houses). I have played through as much of the game as I can, but I cannot find a key item, despite knowing roughly where it is, this is also despite having the key item that should come after it (as far as I know).
SPOILERS:I cannot find the Wind Element, I assume it is in the catacombs but I do not know how to get in there as it appears to have a never ending staircase (as seen in Super Mario 64). I also already have the Fire, Ice and Earth Elements.

Now I suppose we must move onto the bugs I discussed earlier. Some of these have already been mentioned in other reviews, but I will mention them again nonetheless.
- The lighting engine appears to be broken entirely, I didn't realise this until looking at the screenshots now with their lovely lighting, yet my game appears to be running at max brightness with no shadows or dynamic lighting of any kind, the game looks almost completely different without it.
- Many objects are solid for no apparent reason (such as foliage, there are some flowers that are seemingly identical, yet one is solid, the other isn't)
- Many walls aren't solid (e.g. Multiple walls in the Church aren't solid meaning you (and NPCs) can walk on them.
- There's a key that you can pick up In the Ancient Forest in an area with a Waterfall and Cave that I can pick up as many times as I want for no apparent reason, I now have 7 of said key in my inventory.
- This is not necessarily a bug per se, but I noticed that after a couple of hours of playing my ears were beginning to hurt, the sound effects for melee attacks appears to be rather harsh, thankfully I was able to disable this via the RPGMaker menu (F1).

Really I just don't think I can recommend this game, it has too many bugs, combat has become tedious (I avoid as many enemies as I can now), and it just wasn't a particularly fun experience (apart from the first 30min-1hr). Maybe once Secret of Magia gets updated a bit I'll revisit it and update my review, but for now I cannot recommend it.
